author: pscott1337
content:
<@!301186049323958275> or anyone who could answer my question:
I'm trying to adapt my code to support EIP2718.

The first byte (`TransactionType`) must be between `[0, 0x7f]` to be a `TransactionType`. 
I think EIP1559-type transactions are `2`.
So I presume LegacyTransaction are `1` ? If that's the case, is there something for `0`? Or is it left blank on purpose? Thanks! ðŸ™‚

author: lightclient
content: <@!212146572736200704> no EIP-2930 txs are type 1. type 0 is unused

author: pscott1337
content: <@!543900561460822016> got it. It doesn't mean it won't get used in the future, right ?

author: lightclient
content: **yes but i would think it is unlikely

author: pscott1337
content: Since it's a possibility, I'll write my code to support this eventuality haha :p

author: sky.cactus
content: Definitely support `0`.

author: sky.cactus
content: 0x19 is reserved, 0x1 is reserved, and the valid first bytes for legacy transactions are reserved (I forget what they are off the top of my head, I think the EIP notes mentions them).

author: pscott1337
content: (>= `0xc0` I believe :p)

author: pscott1337
content: Yeah supporting `[0, 0x7f]` ! Thanks for your help and your work and your PEEP an EIP  episodes :p

author: pscott1337
content:
It's me again. I think I misunderstood something.
Does `LegacyTransaction` (i.e. regular transactions BEFORE Berlin) have an optional `TransactionType` ?
I think I misunderstood the descrition in the EIP that was

> `Transaction` is either `TransactionType || TransactionPayload` or `LegacyTransaction`

I thought the `or` meant: `TransactionType || TransactionPayload` OR `TransactionType || LegacyTransaction`... but now I *think* I got confused.

The thing that makes me doubt is that the `access_list` of EIP2930 is "optional"... so if I get a `0x01 || LegacyTransaction`, that has NO `access_list`, am I supposed to reject it? Or accept it? ðŸ™‚

author: lightclient
content: you should reject because legacy tx payload != 2930 tx payload

author: lightclient
content: legacy txs do not have an optional type, they must have no type

author: pscott1337
content: ok got it thanks ðŸ™‚

author: _shemnon
content: I vote we treat it like RFC-1149, RFC-2549, RFC-6214, and ignore it 364 days of the year.  They are clearly April fools jokes and can be tolerated on one day out of the year.  It would be good form for authors to move such EIPs to "withdrawn" on 2 April.  Spend zero editorial effort on it.
